item.title: Explore a new way of testing CDI components in Quarkus
item.description: The Quarkus component model is built on top of CDI. However, writing unit tests for beans without a running CDI container is often a tedious work. Without the container services up and running, all the work has to be done manually. First of all, no dependency injection is performed. Furthermore,...
item.author: Martin Kouba (https://twitter.com/martunek)

item.title: Long-Term Support (LTS) for Quarkus
item.description: We’re thrilled to announce the introduction of Long-Term Support (LTS) releases for Quarkus. We aim to strike a balance between our regular high-paced release cycle and the needs of users who require more stability and predictability. LTS releases offer an opportunity for our community to enjoy a version of Quarkus,...
item.author: Max Rydahl Andersen (https://twitter.com/maxandersen)

item.title: Quarkus 3.2.0.Final released - New security features, @QuarkusComponentTest
item.description: It is our pleasure to announce the release of Quarkus 3.2.0.Final. Quarkus 3.2 is the first of the now announced Long Term Support releases of Quarkus. Even if we will maintain 2.16 for a few months still, we encourage all our users to start their migration journey to Quarkus 3....
item.author: Guillaume Smet (https://twitter.com/gsmet_)

item.title: Quarkus 2.16.8.Final released - Maintenance release
item.description: As mentioned in previous blog posts, we encourage all our users to upgrade to Quarkus 3. However we understand the migration can require some time so we will continue to maintain 2.16.x for a while. Today, we released Quarkus 2.16.8.Final, the eighth maintenance release of our 2.16 release train. As...
item.author: Guillaume Smet (https://twitter.com/gsmet_)

item.title: Quarkus 3.1.3.Final released - Maintenance release
item.description: We released Quarkus 3.1.3.Final, the third maintenance release of our 3.1 release train. As usual, it contains bugfixes and documentation improvements. It should be a safe upgrade for anyone already using 3.1. If you are not already using 3.1, please refer to the Quarkus 3.1 migration guide. And if you...
item.author: Guillaume Smet (https://twitter.com/gsmet_)

item.title: Quarkus Native with Podman for Windows
item.description: Developers who use Windows workstations might face the challenge of running Linux-native workflows. One way to achieve this is by using Podman, a container engine that provides a command line capability to run Linux containers. Podman supports running containers both as "rootful" and as "rootless", with the latter being the...
item.author: Karm Michal Babacek (https://twitter.com/_karm)

item.title: Dev productivity - Quarkus CLI
item.description: People hardly realize that the Quarkus CLI was available from the first public release of Quarkus back in 2019. It originally only allowed project creation and extension manipulation. The following command shows the list of supported commands: quarkus --help Usage: quarkus <command> [<args>] These are the common quarkus commands used...
item.author: Ioannis Canellos (https://twitter.com/iocanel)

item.title: Quarkus Newsletter #33 - June
item.description: Check out the June Newsletter.
